title: In a story, how would you describe someone falling? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi! Thanks for the A2A! I’m going to assume you mean actually physically falling rather than something more metaphorical than falling in love with someone or falling asleep. It would depend on things like the cause and manner of the fall, the person who was falling, the height and circumstances of the fall, the reasons for the fall, and how the person falling and the people observing were reacting to such a fall. For instance, a 400-lb man falling into a swimming pool is going to be something you describe very differently than a 3-year-old girl falling into the same pool. One thing might be comical, one thing suspenseful and tragic; or vice versa. Think more about these things and maybe, do some freewriting of phrases that describe all of the things that come to mind as you think about these ideas. You can perhaps begin to construct a good description by doing that. Think about the cause of the fall. Accidental? On purpose? Caused by someone or something else than the person falling? Are there other causes you can think about that evoke the same emotion, and can you use them effectively in a metaphor? i.e., Her slipping on the wet asphalt was unexpected, like rain in February, and just as harsh. Here, you can tell who fell, what caused the fall, and what kind of mood is being created by that fall. Think about the specific character and how you would picture that character falling. Would they not move, and just stare in shock? Would their arms and legs be all akimbo? Would they have any physical time to react? What would they say, or would they be silent, or would they scream? Would their hair fly behind them? What would their eyes and face look like as it happened? What would be passing through the character’s mind? i.e. As the young detective fell from the clock tower, staring incredulously at the mentor who had pushed him, his hands clamored wildly for non-existent handles, and his last thoughts were of betrayal. Here, by addressing the height and circumstances of the fall, you can fill in what the character would do in that situation. This now-flattened detective is sad, betrayed, and frantic in his last moments. Think about the mood, setting and circumstances. Is it a comical pratfall, like in physical comedy? Is it an accidental fall that others find funny? Is it a scary fall that horrifies people, because the character is more than likely hurt? Is this a character falling to their death, doing a graceful dive or a leap of faith? i.e. As she hurled shut-eyed through the lazy iodine skies toward the damp earth below, her heart knew that spreading her wings in the next moment or so was the only thing that would save her from disaster. Here, you can tell that a female character is falling through the sky in an effort to test her ability to fly. She is not nervous, but calm, hopeful, and depending on herself. Good luck! Hope this helped!
